title: Train disabled toilet access to improve after paralympian 'robbed of dignity' | Anglia
text:
The traumatic experience of an Essex Paralympian who was forced to wet herself after she couldn't access a train toilet, will lead to improvements.
The Department for Transport (DfT) announced this morning that Toilet access for all disabled rail passengers will be improved.
It follows the experience of wheelchair racer Anne Wafula-Strike who was on a three-hour journey from Coventry to Stansted Airport just before Christmas when she realised she needed to use the toilet - only to find it was out of order.
With no choice left but to try and hold on, the 42-year-old Harlow athlete hid her face with a hoodie in embarrassment following the incident.
Anne says her dignity was taken away by the episode.
Speaking to ITV News Anglia she said:
While the staff member was apologetic, Anne says the experience has prompted her to speak out about the injustice those with disabilities have to face.
It was bolted up with a big sign saying 'Out of Order'.
When the ticket collector came through, I explained my situation to her and she told me not to worry and said we'd get me off at the next stop.
But unfortunately, when we got to the next stop, the station that she'd suggested had no one at the platform to help.
– – ANNE WAFULA STRIKE The changes was sparked by the incident on CrossCountry trains Rail minister Paul Maynard met with senior industry executives following an incident involving the Team GB athlete.
Now the DfT has urged the rail industry to make sure disabled passengers are told before their train departs if facilities are out of order. It also claimed maintenance teams will ensure accessible toilets are more reliable and fixed faster when problems arise.
"I take the issue of accessibility on our railways extremely seriously and these commitments from industry are just one step forward to improve things.
"It is vital that all people, including disabled passengers, are able to use public transport and I will continue to push train companies on this matter."
– Paul Maynard, Rail Minister It has been a requirement since 1999 that all new trains with toilets are built with accessible toilets as standard, with older trains complying by 2020.
The DfT said 150 stations have been upgraded under the Access for All programme to remove barriers to independent travel, including installing signs, ramps and lifts.
A further 68 are in construction or development.
An Accessibility Action Plan will be published by the DfT later this year to address the issue across all modes of public transport
Last updated Wed 1 Feb 2017 Travel Harlow Essex
